keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was sentenced to five years to life in prison for first-degree rape in Utah, following convictions in August and September 2025 for raping two women in 2008.
Rossi allegedly posed as a dead man, with an obituary claiming his death in February 2020, which authorities later disputed, leading to a lengthy search and international arrest.
He fled the U.S. after being identified through a DNA match from a decade-old rape kit, and was arrested in Scotland in 2024 due to distinctive tattoos recognized by Interpol.
Rossi used multiple aliases, including Arthur Knight, and had a history of evading justice, including failure to register as a sex offender in Rhode Island.
He is described as a 'serial abuser of women' and a 'flight risk,' with prosecutors emphasizing the danger he posed to public safety.
The victim in the first case testified about financial exploitation, emotional manipulation, and a violent rape, which led to her reporting the crime years later.
Rossi did not testify at trial and maintained his innocence, claiming the women were lying and that he was framed.
He is scheduled for sentencing in November 2025 in a second rape case, reflecting ongoing legal consequences for his crimes.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man from Rhode Island, was convicted of first-degree rape in Utah in August and September 2025 for crimes committed in 2008. After being identified through a decade-old DNA match from a rape kit backlog, Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020, with an online obituary falsely claiming he died of lymphoma. He was later arrested in Scotland in 2024 after hospital staff recognized his distinctive tattoos, including one of Brown University, linked to an Interpol notice. He was extradited to Utah in early 2024, where he faced a second trial and conviction. A Utah judge sentenced him to five years to life in prison, citing him as a 'serial abuser' and 'flight risk.' The victim in the first case testified about financial exploitation and abuse, while Rossi maintained his innocence during the trial. He previously failed to register as a sex offender and had a history of using aliases, including Arthur Knight. The case highlights issues of sexual violence, false death claims, and the challenges of tracking and prosecuting serial offenders.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
